text: @A_Bendz yes, that's right.
@A_Bendz It's not much bigger than Earth's orbit, but relative to Earth I'll slowly drift away. Earth will "catch up" with me in ~300 yrs.
@a_bendz Also, there a *lot* of space in heliocentric orbit, so no problem with debris like in Earth orbit.
@a_bendz That would require a VERY big rocket. Slower than that and it'll just end up in an elliptical orbit.
@a_bendz To send a spacecraft on a trajectory into the Sun we'd have to send it "backwards" at around 30km/s - ~3x faster than I'm going!
It was fun while it lasted :-( RT @esascience: On 23 Oct, @Planck will be turned off, completing its 4 year successful mission.
I'm Leaving orbit around L2, and won't be back in the vicinity for a few hundred years. Cheerio all!

text: Welcome to the post-Planck era of cosmology, North America :-) You can view my images on a Planck Chromoscope at http://t.co/goGvPKmIzX
To clarify some (minor) confusion, the maps have about 50million pixels in - each about 2 arcmin (1/30 degree) in size.
Oops - it was Francois Bouchet (not Voucher!) speaking earlier. Blame auto-correct - sorry!
Our first glimpse of polarisation data! But only a little glimpse until next year!
Francois Voucher explaining that lots of different models of inflation are now ruled out
You can watch a scientific description of my results at http://t.co/h5SUcdEfVY
Hope you all like the @Planck @chromoscope page at http://t.co/goGvPKmIzX - we'll be adding more features over time!
RT @esascience: Peeling off layer by layer to reveal the Cosmic Microwave Background. Animation: http://t.co/qyiuO7SOLz #Planck
(The password on the Planck Chromoscope site should now be removed)
@astrofairy should be ok now - thanks!
And if you want to see all 29 scientific papers, you can see them at http://t.co/fbd2QlKAeL
You can see all my frequency and maps of components using a Chromoscope interface - at http://t.co/Vntmib9HXx - enjoy browsing :-)
If you want to ask a question of the panel - tweet #askPlanck :-)
George Efstathiou: Lots more to come - cosmology isn't finished yet!
George Efstathious is being a bit harsh on an example grapefruit for not being perfect on large scales (like the Universe!)
Extrapolating back to the star of the Universe involves going to energies million million times higher than our experiments on Earth.
The large scales anomalies seem to be aligned in a weird way - which so far isn't explained.
But there are some oddities - on very large scales the sky looks a little bit wrong. Seen with WMAP but now known to be really there.
There is no support for weird physics in terms of extra types of neutrinos or changes in dark energy over time
My data has shown that they are indeed smaller at smaller scales - as predicted by inflation!
We used to think that the primordial fluctuations should be the same on all scales - inflation predicts they shouldn't
The age of the Universe is estimated to be 13.82 billion years older - accurate to 0.3%
It agrees very well with models, and allows us to test the composition of the Universe.
George is now showing how the fluctuations in the map vary on different angular scales - the "angular power spectrum"
Now George is comparing my maps with those from the @NASA WMAP satellite!
The foregrounds are "garbage" to cosmologists - though others would disagree!
And on screen now are all nine maps from my two instruments - from 30 GHz up to 850 GHz!
